articles.title: Open science: after the COVID-19 pandemic there can be no return to closed working - The Mandarin
articles.description: Science is largely publicly funded but not publicly accessible. Open access to all research is an ongoing issue. If we are to advance our global effort to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, we must reframe what the standard is.
articles.content: In the few months since the first case of COVID-19 was identified, the underlying cause has been isolated, its symptoms agreed on, its genome sequenced, diagnostic tests developed, and potential treatments and vaccines are on the horizon. The astonishingly sh… [+12887 chars]

articles.title: Children under 10 do not transmit coronavirus to adults - The CEO Magazine
articles.description: A review of evidence by Don't Forget the Bubbles and the UK Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health (RCPCH) found that no child under 10 had transmitted the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, to an adult.
articles.content:
The development comes as public health officials in Switzerland, one of the hardest-hit per capita of the population by the pandemic, announced that under-10s can hug their grandparents again as they pose no risk to them.
Children have been told to stay away… [+3063 chars]

articles.title: Coronavirus Australia: ACT COVID-19 free - Herald Sun
articles.description: There have been no new cases of COVID-19 recorded in the ACT in the past 24 hours. The ACT’s total stands at 106.
articles.content:
There have been no new cases of COVID-19 recorded in the ACT in the past 24 hours. The ACTs total stands at 106.
A total of 103 cases have recovered from COVID-19 and have been released from self-isolation.
There are no active cases in the ACT.

articles.content:

articles.author: Liam Mannix
articles.title: US study finds Ebola drug shows promise, but scientists urge caution - The Age
articles.description: The drug remdesivir appears to significantly speed patients’ recovery from COVID-19, according to preliminary data from US government-sponsored clinical trial.
articles.content:
Two independent Australian scientists called the results promising, while a third cautioned against reading too much into the results until all the data is released.
A separate Chinese trial, high-quality but underpowered and published in the Lancet on Thurs… [+4580 chars]
